canto1.1: Midway upon the journey of our life
canto1.2: I found myself within a forest dark,
canto1.3: For the straightforward pathway had been lost.
canto1.4: Ah me! how hard a thing it is to say
canto1.5: What was this forest savage, rough, and stern,
canto1.6: Which in the very thought renews the fear.
canto1.7: So bitter is it, death is little more;
canto1.8: But of the good to treat, which there I found,
canto1.9: Speak will I of the other things I saw there.
canto1.10: I cannot well repeat how there I entered,
canto1.11: So full was I of slumber at the moment
canto1.12: In which I had abandoned the true way.
canto1.13: But after I had reached a mountain’s foot,
canto1.14: At that point where the valley terminated,
canto1.15: Which had with consternation pierced my heart,
canto1.16: Upward I looked, and I beheld its shoulders,
canto1.17: Vested already with that planet’s rays
canto1.18: Which leadeth others right by every road.
canto1.19: Then was the fear a little quieted
canto1.20: That in my heart’s lake had endured throughout
canto1.21: The night, which I had passed so piteously.
canto1.22: And even as he, who, with distressful breath,
canto1.23: Forth issued from the sea upon the shore,
canto1.24: Turns to the water perilous and gazes;
canto1.25: So did my soul, that still was fleeing onward,
canto1.26: Turn itself back to re-behold the pass
canto1.27: Which never yet a living person left.
canto1.28: After my weary body I had rested,
canto1.29: The way resumed I on the desert slope,
canto1.30: So that the firm foot ever was the lower.
canto1.31: And lo! almost where the ascent began,
canto1.32: A panther light and swift exceedingly,
canto1.33: Which with a spotted skin was covered o’er!
canto1.34: And never moved she from before my face,
canto1.35: Nay, rather did impede so much my way,
canto1.36: That many times I to return had turned.
canto1.37: The time was the beginning of the morning,
canto1.38: And up the sun was mounting with those stars
canto1.39: That with him were, what time the Love Divine
canto1.40: At first in motion set those beauteous things;
canto1.41: So were to me occasion of good hope,
canto1.42: The variegated skin of that wild beast,
canto1.43: The hour of time, and the delicious season;
canto1.44: But not so much, that did not give me fear
canto1.45: A lion’s aspect which appeared to me.
canto1.46: He seemed as if against me he were coming
canto1.47: With head uplifted, and with ravenous hunger,
canto1.48: So that it seemed the air was afraid of him;
canto1.49: And a she-wolf, that with all hungerings
canto1.50: Seemed to be laden in her meagreness,
canto1.51: And many folk has caused to live forlorn!
canto1.52: She brought upon me so much heaviness,
canto1.53: With the affright that from her aspect came,
canto1.54: That I the hope relinquished of the height.
canto1.55: And as he is who willingly acquires,
canto1.56: And the time comes that causes him to lose,
canto1.57: Who weeps in all his thoughts and is despondent,
canto1.58: E’en such made me that beast withouten peace,
canto1.59: Which, coming on against me by degrees
canto1.60: Thrust me back thither where the sun is silent.
canto1.61: While I was rushing downward to the lowland,
canto1.62: Before mine eyes did one present himself,
canto1.63: Who seemed from long-continued silence hoarse.
canto1.64: When I beheld him in the desert vast,
canto1.65: “Have pity on me,” unto him I cried,
canto1.66: “Whiche’er thou art, or shade or real man!”
canto1.67: He answered me: “Not man; man once I was,
canto1.68: And both my parents were of Lombardy,
canto1.69: And Mantuans by country both of them.
canto1.70: ‘Sub Julio’ was I born, though it was late,
canto1.71: And lived at Rome under the good Augustus,
canto1.72: During the time of false and lying gods.
canto1.73: A poet was I, and I sang that just
canto1.74: Son of Anchises, who came forth from Troy,
canto1.75: After that Ilion the superb was burned.
canto1.76: But thou, why goest thou back to such annoyance?
canto1.77: Why climb’st thou not the Mount Delectable,
canto1.78: Which is the source and cause of every joy?”
canto1.79: “Now, art thou that Virgilius and that fountain
canto1.80: Which spreads abroad so wide a river of speech?”
canto1.81: I made response to him with bashful forehead.
canto1.82: “O, of the other poets honour and light,
canto1.83: Avail me the long study and great love
canto1.84: That have impelled me to explore thy volume!
canto1.85: Thou art my master, and my author thou,
canto1.86: Thou art alone the one from whom I took
canto1.87: The beautiful style that has done honour to me.
canto1.88: Behold the beast, for which I have turned back;
canto1.89: Do thou protect me from her, famous Sage,
canto1.90: For she doth make my veins and pulses tremble.”
canto1.91: “Thee it behoves to take another road,”
canto1.92: Responded he, when he beheld me weeping,
canto1.93: “If from this savage place thou wouldst escape;
canto1.94: Because this beast, at which thou criest out,
canto1.95: Suffers not any one to pass her way,
canto1.96: But so doth harass him, that she destroys him;
canto1.97: And has a nature so malign and ruthless,
canto1.98: That never doth she glut her greedy will,
canto1.99: And after food is hungrier than before.
canto1.100: Many the animals with whom she weds,
canto1.101: And more they shall be still, until the Greyhound
canto1.102: Comes, who shall make her perish in her pain.
canto1.103: He shall not feed on either earth or pelf,
canto1.104: But upon wisdom, and on love and virtue;
canto1.105: ’Twixt Feltro and Feltro shall his nation be;
canto1.106: Of that low Italy shall he be the saviour,
canto1.107: On whose account the maid Camilla died,
canto1.108: Euryalus, Turnus, Nisus, of their wounds;
canto1.109: Through every city shall he hunt her down,
canto1.110: Until he shall have driven her back to Hell,
canto1.111: There from whence envy first did let her loose.
canto1.112: Therefore I think and judge it for thy best
canto1.113: Thou follow me, and I will be thy guide,
canto1.114: And lead thee hence through the eternal place,
canto1.115: Where thou shalt hear the desperate lamentations,
canto1.116: Shalt see the ancient spirits disconsolate,
canto1.117: Who cry out each one for the second death;
canto1.118: And thou shalt see those who contented are
canto1.119: Within the fire, because they hope to come,
canto1.120: Whene’er it may be, to the blessed people;
canto1.121: To whom, then, if thou wishest to ascend,
canto1.122: A soul shall be for that than I more worthy;
canto1.123: With her at my departure I will leave thee;
canto1.124: Because that Emperor, who reigns above,
canto1.125: In that I was rebellious to his law,
canto1.126: Wills that through me none come into his city.
canto1.127: He governs everywhere, and there he reigns;
canto1.128: There is his city and his lofty throne;
canto1.129: O happy he whom thereto he elects!”
canto1.130: And I to him: “Poet, I thee entreat,
canto1.131: By that same God whom thou didst never know,
canto1.132: So that I may escape this woe and worse,
canto1.133: Thou wouldst conduct me there where thou hast said,
canto1.134: That I may see the portal of Saint Peter,
canto1.135: And those thou makest so disconsolate.”
canto1.136: Then he moved on, and I behind him followed.

canto2.1: Day was departing, and the embrowned air
canto2.2: Released the animals that are on earth
canto2.3: From their fatigues; and I the only one
canto2.4: Made myself ready to sustain the war,
canto2.5: Both of the way and likewise of the woe,
canto2.6: Which memory that errs not shall retrace.
canto2.7: O Muses, O high genius, now assist me!
canto2.8: O memory, that didst write down what I saw,
canto2.9: Here thy nobility shall be manifest!
canto2.10: And I began: “Poet, who guidest me,
canto2.11: Regard my manhood, if it be sufficient,
canto2.12: Ere to the arduous pass thou dost confide me.
canto2.13: Thou sayest, that of Silvius the parent,
canto2.14: While yet corruptible, unto the world
canto2.15: Immortal went, and was there bodily.
canto2.16: But if the adversary of all evil
canto2.17: Was courteous, thinking of the high effect
canto2.18: That issue would from him, and who, and what,
canto2.19: To men of intellect unmeet it seems not;
canto2.20: For he was of great Rome, and of her empire
canto2.21: In the empyreal heaven as father chosen;
canto2.22: The which and what, wishing to speak the truth,
canto2.23: Were stablished as the holy place, wherein
canto2.24: Sits the successor of the greatest Peter.
canto2.25: Upon this journey, whence thou givest him vaunt,
canto2.26: Things did he hear, which the occasion were
canto2.27: Both of his victory and the papal mantle.
canto2.28: Thither went afterwards the Chosen Vessel,
canto2.29: To bring back comfort thence unto that Faith,
canto2.30: Which of salvation’s way is the beginning.
canto2.31: But I, why thither come, or who concedes it?
canto2.32: I not Aeneas am, I am not Paul,
canto2.33: Nor I, nor others, think me worthy of it.
canto2.34: Therefore, if I resign myself to come,
canto2.35: I fear the coming may be ill-advised;
canto2.36: Thou’rt wise, and knowest better than I speak.”
canto2.37: And as he is, who unwills what he willed,
canto2.38: And by new thoughts doth his intention change,
canto2.39: So that from his design he quite withdraws,
canto2.40: Such I became, upon that dark hillside,
canto2.41: Because, in thinking, I consumed the emprise,
canto2.42: Which was so very prompt in the beginning.
canto2.43: “If I have well thy language understood,”
canto2.44: Replied that shade of the Magnanimous,
canto2.46: Which many times a man encumbers so,
canto2.47: It turns him back from honoured enterprise,
canto2.48: As false sight doth a beast, when he is shy.
canto2.49: That thou mayst free thee from this apprehension,
canto2.50: I’ll tell thee why I came, and what I heard
canto2.51: At the first moment when I grieved for thee.
canto2.52: Among those was I who are in suspense,
canto2.53: And a fair, saintly Lady called to me
canto2.54: In such wise, I besought her to command me.
canto2.55: Her eyes where shining brighter than the Star;
canto2.56: And she began to say, gentle and low,
canto2.57: With voice angelical, in her own language:
canto2.59: Of whom the fame still in the world endures,
canto2.60: And shall endure, long-lasting as the world;
canto2.61: A friend of mine, and not the friend of fortune,
canto2.62: Upon the desert slope is so impeded
canto2.63: Upon his way, that he has turned through terror,
canto2.64: And may, I fear, already be so lost,
canto2.65: That I too late have risen to his succour,
canto2.66: From that which I have heard of him in Heaven.
canto2.67: Bestir thee now, and with thy speech ornate,
canto2.68: And with what needful is for his release,
canto2.69: Assist him so, that I may be consoled.
canto2.70: Beatrice am I, who do bid thee go;
canto2.71: I come from there, where I would fain return;
canto2.72: Love moved me, which compelleth me to speak.
canto2.73: When I shall be in presence of my Lord,
canto2.74: Full often will I praise thee unto him.’
canto2.75: Then paused she, and thereafter I began:
canto2.76: ‘O Lady of virtue, thou alone through whom
canto2.77: The human race exceedeth all contained
canto2.78: Within the heaven that has the lesser circles,
canto2.79: So grateful unto me is thy commandment,
canto2.80: To obey, if ’twere already done, were late;
canto2.81: No farther need’st thou ope to me thy wish.
canto2.82: But the cause tell me why thou dost not shun
canto2.83: The here descending down into this centre,
canto2.84: From the vast place thou burnest to return to.’
canto2.85: ‘Since thou wouldst fain so inwardly discern,
canto2.86: Briefly will I relate,’ she answered me,
canto2.87: ‘Why I am not afraid to enter here.
canto2.88: Of those things only should one be afraid
canto2.89: Which have the power of doing others harm;
canto2.90: Of the rest, no; because they are not fearful.
canto2.91: God in his mercy such created me
canto2.92: That misery of yours attains me not,
canto2.93: Nor any flame assails me of this burning.
canto2.94: A gentle Lady is in Heaven, who grieves
canto2.95: At this impediment, to which I send thee,
canto2.96: So that stern judgment there above is broken.
canto2.97: In her entreaty she besought Lucia,
canto2.98: And said, “Thy faithful one now stands in need
canto2.99: Of thee, and unto thee I recommend him.”
canto2.100: Lucia, foe of all that cruel is,
canto2.101: Hastened away, and came unto the place
canto2.102: Where I was sitting with the ancient Rachel.
canto2.103: “Beatrice” said she, “the true praise of God,
canto2.104: Why succourest thou not him, who loved thee so,
canto2.105: For thee he issued from the vulgar herd?
canto2.106: Dost thou not hear the pity of his plaint?
canto2.107: Dost thou not see the death that combats him
canto2.108: Beside that flood, where ocean has no vaunt?”
canto2.109: Never were persons in the world so swift
canto2.110: To work their weal and to escape their woe,
canto2.111: As I, after such words as these were uttered,
canto2.112: Came hither downward from my blessed seat,
canto2.114: Which honours thee, and those who’ve listened to it.’
canto2.115: After she thus had spoken unto me,
canto2.116: Weeping, her shining eyes she turned away;
canto2.117: Whereby she made me swifter in my coming;
canto2.118: And unto thee I came, as she desired;
canto2.119: I have delivered thee from that wild beast,
canto2.120: Which barred the beautiful mountain’s short ascent.
canto2.121: What is it, then?  Why, why dost thou delay?
canto2.122: Why is such baseness bedded in thy heart?
canto2.123: Daring and hardihood why hast thou not,
canto2.124: Seeing that three such Ladies benedight
canto2.125: Are caring for thee in the court of Heaven,
canto2.126: And so much good my speech doth promise thee?”
canto2.127: Even as the flowerets, by nocturnal chill,
canto2.128: Bowed down and closed, when the sun whitens them,
canto2.129: Uplift themselves all open on their stems;
canto2.130: Such I became with my exhausted strength,
canto2.131: And such good courage to my heart there coursed,
canto2.132: That I began, like an intrepid person:
canto2.134: And courteous thou, who hast obeyed so soon
canto2.135: The words of truth which she addressed to thee!
canto2.136: Thou hast my heart so with desire disposed
canto2.137: To the adventure, with these words of thine,
canto2.138: That to my first intent I have returned.
canto2.139: Now go, for one sole will is in us both,
canto2.140: Thou Leader, and thou Lord, and Master thou.”
canto2.141: Thus said I to him; and when he had moved,
canto2.142: I entered on the deep and savage way.
